title: 106_hr263
content: The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes an excise tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payments in factoring transactions, as outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new chapter addresses structured settlement factoring transactions. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes a 50 percent tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payment rights in factoring transactions, with exceptions for court-approved hardship cases. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" allows for the transfer of structured settlement payment rights under certain conditions, including court approval for cases of extraordinary financial need. The term 'structured settlement' refers to an arrangement for periodic payments of damages or compensation that are excluded from the recipient's gross income under specific sections of the law. The structured settlement involves periodic payments of compensation under workers' compensation acts that are excludable from gross income. The payments must meet specific criteria and be payable by a party to the suit or agreement. The term 'structured settlement payment rights' refers to the rights to receive payments under a structured settlement. 'Structured settlement factoring transaction' is defined as a transaction involving the sale of structured settlement payment rights. The term 'structured settlement payment rights' refers to rights to receive payments under a structured settlement. A 'structured settlement factoring transaction' involves the transfer of these payment rights for consideration through sale, assignment, pledge, or other forms of encumbrance. The term 'factoring discount' refers to the excess amount paid by the acquirer for structured settlement payments over the total amount paid to the seller. The term 'relevant court or administrative authority' refers to the court or administrative body overseeing the transaction. The term 'relevant court or administrative authority' in structured settlement payments refers to the court or administrative body with jurisdiction over the underlying action or proceeding resolved by the structured settlement. The relevant court or administrative authority for structured settlement payments is the one with jurisdiction over the claim or the residence of the recipient. Coordination with other provisions like sections 72, 130, and 461(h) must be ensured. The structured settlement recipient's residence is crucial for the relevant court or administrative authority. Coordination with sections 72, 130, and 461(h) is necessary to ensure compliance with the applicable requirements. The occurrence of a structured settlement factoring transaction should not impact the provisions of these sections for the parties involved. The Secretary has the authority to issue regulations in this regard. The Secretary can issue regulations regarding structured settlement factoring transactions and the treatment of amounts received by the structured settlement recipient. Additionally, a new section on information reporting is added to the relevant part of the tax code. SEC. 6050T. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS REGARDING STRUCTURED SETTLEMENT FACTORING TRANSACTIONS. "In structured settlement factoring transactions, the person making the payments must provide a return and written statement to the acquirer of the payment rights as required by section 6041, or be subject to tax under section 5891." "In structured settlement factoring transactions, the person making the payments must provide a return and written statement to the acquirer of the payment rights as required by section 6041, or be subject to tax under section 5891. The reporting obligations outlined in this section apply instead of any other provisions in this part." The Secretary shall prescribe regulations for reporting obligations in structured settlement factoring transactions, replacing other provisions in this part. Withholding rules under section 3405 do not apply in these transactions. The term 'acquirer of the structured settlement payment rights' includes persons in section 7701(a)(1). The term 'acquirer of the structured settlement payment rights' includes any person described in section 7701(a)(1). Clerical amendments are made to the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code. Chapter 55 introduces reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions under Sec. 6050T of the tax code. Reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions under Sec. 6050T of the tax code will apply to transactions occurring after the enactment of this Act.
